ofx:section.ofx:title: Secure Shell (SSH)
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph:
The Secure Shell (SSH) is a cryptographic network protocol for secure data communication, remote command-line login, remote command execution, and other secure network services between two networked computers. For this system it is used for the administrator to remotely login to the system and excute shell commands.
ssh IP-ADRESS -l USERNAME
Execute the following commands with root rights: su -

A common used best practice for running SSH on a server is to deactivate the authentication by password and the permission for the user root to log in remotely. For editing the file below you can use the nano editor. nano /etc/ssh/sshd-config

ofx:section.ofx:title: Cryptographic Keys
ofx:section.ofx:paragraph: First of all, a cryptographic key has to be generated on the computer of the user. This procedure varies for different operating system, here the process for Linux is described.
The public part of this key (key.pub) has to be appended to the file .authorizedkeys.
Then, the server configuration "-config" in etc/ssh/sshd-config has to be updated.
